Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Targeted resampling of deep polar ice cores using information theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ice cores contain detailed accounts of Earth's climate history. The collection of an ice core can be logistically challenging, and extraction of data from the core can be time-consuming as well as susceptible to both human and machine error. Furthermore, locked in measurements from ice cores is information that scientists have not yet found ways to recover. This project will apply techniques from information theory to ice-core data to unlock that information. The primary goal is to demonstrate that information theory can (a) identify regions of a specific ice-core record that are in need of further analysis and (b) provide some specific guidance for that analysis. A secondary goal is to demonstrate that information theory has practical and scientific utility for studies of past climate.

This project aims to use information theory in two distinct ways: first, to identify regions of a core where information appears to be damaged or missing, perhaps due to human and/or machine error. In the segment of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide core that is 5000-8000 years old, for instance, information-theoretic methods reveal significant levels of noise, probably due to a laboratory instrument, and something that was not visible in the raw data. This is a particularly important segment of the record, as it contains valuable clues about climatic shifts and the onset of the Holocene. Targeted re-sampling of this segment of the core and reanalysis with newer laboratory apparatus could resolve the data issues. The second way in which information theory can potentially aid in ice-core analysis is by extracting climate signals from the data--such as the accumulation rate at the core site over the period of its formation. This quantity usually requires significant time and effort to produce, but information theory could help to streamline that process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has two major goals. The primary goal is to use information theory to identify intervals of data in ice core records in which substantially new information is produced, warranting further investigation. For these intervals, the most likely cause of the new information is either laboratory error or a real climate signal. The secondary goal is to develop methodologies that make information theory useful as a forensic tool in climate studies. For ice core water isotope records in particular, information about the accumulation rate, diffusion, and climate can potentially be extracted.


Ice core science has progressed substantially in the last few decades. For studies of water isotopes in deep ice cores, older records yielded 5cm resolution, whereas new laser-based, continuous measurement technologies yield millimeter resolution. This has increased data density from the thousands into the millions for multi-kilometer ice cores. For newer, larger data sets, it is not possible to check the data manually for error. As part of this project, we scanned the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide ice core (WDC) for information production anomalies using weighted permutation entropy (WPE) and permutation entropy (PE), both calculations grouped within the broader field of information theory. The WDC water isotope record includes 24 million data points spread across 3 different variables: dD, d18O, and deuterium excess. We found numerous short intervals less than a few years in length that required correction for laboratory error, or in the case of Holocene ice we resampled and reanalyzed over 300 meters of ice from 4.5 - 6.5 thousand years before present. This new data showed no anomaly in WPE/PE and had significantly less high-frequency noise. This fulfilled the primary goal of the study, to identify intervals of ice with anomalous WPE/PE results, and correct them for laboratory error if possible.


Water isotopes are substantially changed in the firn column of an ice sheet due to diffusion, and WPE/PE can detect this change. The firn column comprises the upper 50-100 m of the ice sheet, with interconnected vapor pathways that allow for the diffusion of water vapor. Beneath the firn, the pathways close off into solid ice. In Community Firn Model (CFM) tests, we demonstrated that WPE of a water isotope signal is very similar to the annual accumulation rate, due to the effects of water isotope diffusion in the firn. We explored whether WPE could be used to reconstruct the accumulation rate in an ice core, but concluded that this is not possible. Instead, the pattern of WPE of water isotopes can be used in comparison with a separately calculated accumulation rate, and if there are substantial differences in the traces, this is a forensic clue that suggests additional investigation is necessary to reconcile the discrepancies. This partially fulfilled the secondary goal of the study, to develop methodologies that make information theory useful as a forensic tool in climate studies.


Using the updated Holocene record (0-11 thousand years), we explored seasonal and annual water isotope variability in the WDC record. In particular, we separated summer and winter isotopic data to explore climatological differences across seasons. This analysis would not have been possible for data in the interval of 4.5-6.5 thousand years, where the high-frequency noise detected by WPE/PE would have introduced artifacts arising from laboratory analysis, rather than a true climate signal. Our analysis is the first time that seasonal information (summer, winter) has been extracted from any paleoclimate record spanning the entire Holocene. Our results are in line with Milankovitch Theory, with the summer record tracking with orbital forcing, and the winter record probably arising from remnants of the summer forcing, teleconnections to lower latitudes, and random climate events. We can also definitively show that the mean value of our record is dominated in the early Holocene by winter variability, and in the mid-to-late Holocene by summer variability. This goes to show that paleoclimate proxy records should not be interpreted as solely summer or winter records, when in fact, it can be a mix of both. This result partially fulfilled the secondary goal of the study, utilizing WPE/PE as a tool to improve the extraction of climate signals in paleoclimate records.  


This project resulted in 3 peer reviewed publications. The results were presented at professional conferences including the American Geophysical Union in San Francisco, at science night at the EGRIP ice core camp in Greenland, and at the EGRIP steering committee meeting in Copenhagen. An undergraduate student was employed during this project and trained to learn varying forms of information theory. A professional lab technician was also trained. The WPE/PE information detection algorithm has been incorporated in multiple new ice core projects, is used by multiple international labs, and will commonly be used as a quality control metric in future projects.
